content:
• Wednesday, July 31, 2013

  • Shanghai, Tokyo move higher after Fed, China data

    • The Shanghai Composite rises 1.3% following a better than expected official PMI print. The Hang Seng is up 1%.
    • The Nikkei jumps 1.16% as the yen falls 0.3% against the dollar to Â¥98.18.
    • Not along for the ride are Australian equities, which are off 0.3% in Sydney. The aussie trades near a three-year low sliding 0.26% to 0.8957.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:14 PM
  • PPC

    More on Pilgrims Pride earnings

    • Pilgrim's Pride (NYSE:PPC) Q2 comes in line on revenue but beats on a per share basis.
    • Net profit more than doubled as gross margins widened to 12.9% from 7.3%, boosted by sales improvements that outpaced growth in input costs.
    • Shares +1.8% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:09 PM
  • WDC

    SanDisk initiates $0.225/share dividend, adds $2.5B to buyback plan

    • The quarterly dividend is good for a 1.6% yield.
    • $1B of the $2.5B in buybacks will take place via an accelerated repurchase program with an unnamed financial institution.
    • Excluding the program, and including funds remaining on an existing $1.25B authorization, SanDisk has $2.1B in available buyback funds, good for repurchasing 15% of outstanding shares at current levels.
    • SNDK +4.4% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:16 PM
  • SPWR

    SunPower reverses course, now -2.6% AH on mixed Q2, guidance

    • SunPower's (NASDAQ:SPWR) Q2 EPS beat had much to do with a gross margin of 19.5%, -320 bps Q/Q but +480 bps Y/Y and well above guidance of 14%-16%. SunPower attributes the gains to cost reductions.
    • Full-year GM guidance is now at 18%-20%, above a prior 15%-17%. Q3 GM guidance of 17%-19%.
    • SunPower still expects to recognize 1GW-1.1GW in module shipments in 2013. 277MW were recognized in Q2, near the high end of a guidance range of 260MW-280MW. 240MW-260MW expected in Q3.
    • Q2 Americas sales (68% of revenue) -1% Y/Y. EMEA -31%. Asia-Pac +110%, thanks in part to 30% Q/Q growth in Japan.
    • Americas GM was 22.5% in Q2, -1000 bps Q/Q and +340 bps Y/Y. EMEA GM was 9.7% after being negative for three straight quarters. Asia-Pac came in at 16.6%.
    • All of SunPower's plants are running at 100% utilization.
    • Shares +391% YTD going into the report.
    • Q2 results, PR, slides, datasheet
     
     
     
     
    | 7:10 PM
  • CBS

    More on CBS earnings

    • CBS (NYSE:CBS) Q2 beats on all counts as total revenue rises by 11% Y/Y.
    • Net profit also rose 10.5%, boosted by digital streaming and international syndication deals, higher fees paid by pay TV operators to carry CBS-owned TV stations as well as sports programming.
    • Advertising revenue, which contributes more than half of the company's top line, grew 4.7% to $2.09B, lifted by higher advertising revenue from the NCAA Men's Basketball Championship semifinals.
    • Shares +1.2% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:21 PM
  • CTRP

    Ctrip.com beats by $0.07, beats on revenue

    • Ctrip.com (NASDAQ:CTRP): Q2 EPS of $0.36 beats by $0.07.
    • Revenue of $203M beats by $12.59M. Shares +1.6% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 6:16 PM
  • DX

    Dynex Capital beats by $0.22

    • Dynex Capital (NYSE:DX): Q2 EPS of $0.54 beats by $0.22. Shares -9.6% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 6:14 PM
  • ROVI

    Rovi -4.4% AH due to revenue miss, guidance; company selling 2 businesses

    • ROVI has reached deals to sell its struggling Entertainment Store (private-label digital content sales) and Consumer Website businesses. The former has been on the block since January.
    • Rovi now expects 2013 revenue of $600M-$630M and EPS of $1.80-$2.10, below a prior forecast of $630M-$660M, and largely below consensus of $645.4M and $2.09.
    • The Consumer Website sale has a $7M-$9M impact on revenue guidance. For the rest, Rovi blames "uncertainties with respect to the timing of closing several new [licensing] agreements" with international and over-the-top (i.e. Internet video) companies. Rovi remains mired in a legal battle with Netflix and Roku.
    • Revenue -5% Y/Y in Q2. Service provider revenue +10% to $83.7M, but consumer electronics businesses -27% $47.3M.
    • $65M was spent on buybacks in Q2.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 6:00 PM
  • LRCX

    Lam Research -2.4% AH thanks to light guidance

    • Though Lam's (NASDAQ:LRCX) FQ4 results beat estimates, the chip equipment maker expects FQ1 revenue of $1B (+/- $30M) and EPS of $0.68 (+/- $0.07), which is unfavorable to a consensus of $1.04B and $0.83.
    • FQ1 shipments are also expected to total $1B (+/- $30M).
    • FQ4 gross margin +60 bps Q/Q to 43.5%, deferred revenue +19% Q/Q to $389.2M. FQ1 gross margin guidance of 44% (+/- 1%).
    • FQ4 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:40 PM
  • STMP

    Stamps.com beats by $0.13, beats on revenue

    • Stamps.com (NASDAQ:STMP): Q2 EPS of $0.60 beats by $0.13.
    • Revenue of $32.1M (+14% Y/Y) beats by $0.65M. Shares +7.7% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:39 PM
  • DX

    Dynex book value sinks 14.9% in Q2

    • Book value per share declines 14.9% to $8.94.
    • EPS of $29.4M or $0.54/share includes fair value adjustments (related to long-term rate swaps not subject to hedge accounting) of $10.7M or $0.20/share. Backing that out brings EPS to a more inline $0.34.
    • Net interest spread of 1.75% vs. 1.89% in Q1.
    • Leverage increases to 6.8x from 6.3x.
    • CPR of 21% vs. 19.3% in Q1, 14.3% a year ago.
    • Management notes it wasn't so much the rise in interest rates during the quarter as it was the widening in credit spreads, meaning hybrid REITs (see Invesco earlier) had no advantage over their agency brethren when it came to preserving book value.
    • Earnings call at at 11 ET. (PR)
    • DX -9.4% AH to $8.71.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:37 PM | 1 Comment
  • RGR

    More on Sturm Ruger earnings

    • Sturm, Ruger (NYSE:RGR) Q2 beats across the board.
    • Net earnings increased 79%, driven by 50% growth in sales and ongoing focus on improvement in operations.
    • New product introductions, including the LC380 and SR45 pistols, were a significant component of sales growth, representing 31% of firearm sales in the first half of 2013.
    • Estimated unit sell-through of products from the independent distributors to retailers increased 37 from comparable prior year periods.
    • Shares +5.2% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:34 PM | 1 Comment
  • SGEN

    Seattle Genetics reports Q2 results, Adcetris sales tick higher

    • Seattle Genetics' (NASDAQ:SGEN) Q2 results top estimates.
    • Adcetris sales for the period were $35.7M. That's up slightly from Q2 2012 sales of $34.7M and Q1 sales of $33.9M. Consensus was $34.2M. (PR)
    • Shares -2.44% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:33 PM

  • After-hours top gainers / Losers

    • After-hours top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: RKUS +11%. STMP +9%. AFFX +8%. TRLA +8%. THOR-OLD +8%.
    •  losers: GRMN -7%. TBBK -6%. SLCA -6%. ROVI -4%. CAVM -4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:30 PM
  • PXD

    Pioneer Natural Resources pops 10 points AH following earnings

    • Pioneer Natural Resources' (NYSE:PXD) Q2 earnings fell short of estimates, but oil and gas revenue rose 31.7% Y/Y to $845M.
    • Production grew 3%; average prices rose 13%, including 2.8% growth for oil and 87% for natural gas that offset a 14% decline for natural gas liquids.
    • Q3 production is forecast to average 174M-179M boe/day, assuming output in the Spraberry/Wolfcamp area will be negatively impacted by~2M boe/day from ethane rejection due to low ethane prices; production costs are expected to average $14-$16/boe.
    • Shares +6% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:25 PM
  • SLCA

    U.S. Silica misses by $0.02, misses on revenue

    • U.S. Silica (NYSE:SLCA): Q2 EPS of $0.38 misses by $0.02.
    • Revenue of $129.8M (+24% Y/Y) misses by $4.77M. Shares -9.1% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:08 PM | 1 Comment
  • SAM

    Boston Beer tops estimates, lifts guidance

    • Boston Beer (NYSE:SAM) beats on the top and bottom line.
    • Core shipment growth of 21% Y/Y. Depletions growth comes in at 24%.
    • Gross margin of 54%. (PR)
    • FY13 outlook is raised: Depletions growth of 17-22% (from 10-15%), EPS of $5.10-5.40 (from $4.70-5.10), capex of $100-140M (from $85-105M).
    • Shares +5% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:02 PM | 1 Comment
  • OTEX

    Open Text EPS in-line, misses on revenue

    • Open Text (NASDAQ:OTEX): FQ4 EPS of $1.43 in-line.
    • Revenue of $347.3M (+14% Y/Y) misses by $13.75M. Shares -5.7% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:02 PM
  • WBMD

    WebMD misses by $0.01, beats on revenue

    • WebMD (NASDAQ:WBMD): Q2 EPS of $0.05 misses by $0.01.
    • Revenue of $125.3M beats by $0.9M. Shares -1.9% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:48 PM
  • SFLY

    Shutterfly beats by $0.26, beats on revenue

    • Shutterfly (NASDAQ:SFLY): Q2 EPS of -$0.29 beats by $0.26.
    • Revenue of $133.5M (+35% Y/Y) beats by $11.5M. Shares +2.6% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:42 PM
  • Z

    Trulia beats by $0.01, beats on revenue

    • Trulia (TRLA): Q2 EPS of $0.05 beats by $0.01.
    • Revenue of $29.7M (+77% Y/Y) beats by $2.01M. Shares +9.9% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:37 PM
  • PCYC

    Pharmacyclics tops estimates for Q2

    • Pharmacyclics' (NASDAQ:PCYC) Q2 comes in ahead of Street estimates.
    • Shares +2.18% AH.
    • Revenue of $54.2M is primarily attributable to a $50M milestone payment (from Janssen) tied to the enrollment of a fifth patient in a trial testing ibrutinib for the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia and small lymphocytic lymphoma.That's the fourth such payment to date.
    • PCYC recognized a $17.4M reduction in R&D expense for the quarter due to its capped development cost deal with Janssen. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:37 PM
  • RKUS

    Ruckus +10.1% AH thanks to Q2 beat, in-line guidance, low expectations

    • Ruckus' (NYSE:RKUS) Q3 guidance is for revenue of $66M-$69M and EPS of $0.04 vs. a consensus of $67.6M and $0.04.
    • Q2 beat fueled by 62% Y/Y EMEA growth. Americas +31%.
    • 2.9K new enterprise end-customers added.
    • Shares were crushed in May thanks to a Q1 miss and light guidance, leaving investor expectations low.
    • Piper's bullish coverage launch and Needham's upgrade look smart.
    • CC at 5PM ET (webcast)
    • Enterprise/carrier Wi-Fi rival Aruba (NASDAQ:ARUN), whose shares have also plunged, is up 0.7%.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:30 PM
  • QUIK

    QuickLogic beats by $0.01, beats on revenue

    • QuickLogic (NASDAQ:QUIK): Q2 EPS of -$0.05 beats by $0.01.
    • Revenue of $5.1M (+26% Y/Y) beats by $0.8M. Shares +3.6% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:30 PM
  • YELP

    Yelp's Q3/2013 guidance strong, shares +5% AH

    • Yelp (NYSE:YELP) expects Q3 revenue of $58M-$59M, above a $57.4M consensus.
    • 2013 guidance is for revenue of $222M-$224M and adjusted EBITDA of $27M-$28M, above prior guidance of $216M-$218M and $21M-$23M. Revenue consensus is at $220M.
    • Cumulative reviews +41% Y/Y to 42.5M (+42% in Q1), average monthly unique visitors +38% to 108M (+43% prior), active local business accounts +62% to 51.4K (+63% prior).
    • CC atÂ  4:30PM ET (webcast)
    • Q2 results, PR, earnings slides
     
     
     
     
    | 4:22 PM
  • AMZN

    More on Whole Foods Market's FQ3

    • Comparable store sales rose 7.5% during the quarter while gross profit increased 61 bps to 36.6% as a percentage of total sales.
    • The development pipeline is now up to 94 leases and "accelerating" square footage growth is expected for several more years.
    • Whole Foods Market (WFM) sees full-year EPS of $1.45-$1.46 vs. $1.45 consensus. (PR)
    • WFM -0.4% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:18 PM
  • DWA

    DreamWorks rises on earnings beat

    • DreamWorks (NASDAQ:DWA)Â beats on the top and bottom line for Q2. Revenue rises 31% Y/Y.
    • Shares +6.62% AH.
    • The Croods "incredibly successful box office run" contributes $71.8M in revenue for the period.
    • CEOÂ Jeffrey Katzenberg emphasizes diversification, saying DWA has "a great deal of momentum within [the] television, consumer products and location-based entertainment businesses."
    • Q3 results will be driven by "worldwide pay television revenue for Rise of the Guardians and international free television for Kung Fu Panda 2." (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM | 1 Comment
  • TRN

    Trinity Industries beats by $0.11, beats on revenue

    • Trinity Industries (NYSE:TRN): Q2 EPS of $1.06 beats by $0.11.
    • Revenue of $1.1B (+7% Y/Y) beats by $0.08B. Shares +2.3% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:16 PM
  • SPWR

    SunPower EPS beats by $0.37, revenue misses by $3M

    • SunPower (NASDAQ:SPWR): Q2 EPS of $0.48 beats by $0.37.
    • Revenue of $576.5M (-3% Y/Y) misses by $3M.
    • Expects Q3 revenue of $550M-$600M and EPS of $0.15-$0.35 vs. a consensus of $682.2M and $0.19.
    • Expects 2013 revenue of $2.5B-$2.6B and EPS of $1-$1.30 vs. a consensus of $2.57B and $0.77.
    • Shares +3.3% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:13 PM
  • BYD

    Boyd Gaming announces a 15M share secondary offering

    • Boyd Gaming (NYSE:BYD) announces a 15M share secondary offering, with a 30-day option for underwriters to purchase up to an additional 2,250,000 shares for over allotments if needed.
    • The Company intends to use the net proceeds to redeem a portion of the its 7.125% Senior Subordinated Notes due 2016 and for general corporate purposes.
    • Deutsche Bank and JPMorgan are acting as joint book-runners.
    • Shares -6.2% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:11 PM
  • YELP

    Yelp beats by $0.03, beats on revenue

    • Yelp (NYSE:YELP): Q2 EPS of -$0.01 beats by $0.03.
    • Revenue of $55M (+69% Y/Y) beats by $1.7M. Shares +3.7% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:10 PM
  • JCP

    J.C. Penney's credit issues in focus

    • Retail Sails is out with a quick response to The New York Post story indicating J.C. Penney (NYSE:JCP) is having credit issues. The research firm says its sources tip off the retailer is still receiving factoring services from firms other than CIT.
    • JCP +0.7% AH after a 10.2% drop on the day.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:05 PM | 3 Comments
  • SUN

    Susser Petroleum Partners started with Buy at Benchmark

    • Susser Petroleum Partners (SUSP +1.9%) is initiated with a Buy rating and a $35 price target at Benchmark, seeing upside potential given SUSP's growth and operating margin opportunities.
    • Given steady profitability and management's consistent execution, the firm believes shares are not trading at their full value.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM
  • BXC

    BlueLinx takes a hit on widening net losses

    • BlueLinx (BXC -9.8%) takes a hit today as Q2 net losses widened significantly. (10-Q)
    • Q2 revenues increased 16.9% to $604.6M from $517M for the same period a year ago, but the company incurred a net loss of $22.3M, or $0.27 per diluted share.
    • This compares with a net loss of $3.7M, or $0.06 per diluted share, for Q212.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:52 PM
  • JCP

    J.C. Penney tanks on new credit concerns

    • Shares of J.C. Penney (JCP -9.5%) nosedive after The New York Post reports the retailer is having more credit problems.
    • Sources indicate commercial lender CIT has stopped supporting deliveries from small manufacturers to J.C. Penney stores on credit fears.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:48 PM | 6 Comments
  • NVLN

    Aegerion higher again on Juxtapid outlook

    • All aboard the Aegerion (AEGR +10.4%) train! The company's upbeat outlook for Juxtapid sales has the stock moving sharply higher again today.
    • Jefferies (Buy) raises the price target on the shares to $92 from $82 noting accelerating weekly scripts data. Analyst Eun Yang also says "<10% dropout rate and ~7% gross-to-net discount are encouraging."
    • Tip of the hat to SA Pro contributor Cory Renauer who penned a bullish Juxtapid piece back on June 12 — that was some 25% ago.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:46 PM | 3 Comments

  • Gold erases loss following FOMC

    • Down nearly 2% and flirting with falling below $1,300 per ounce, gold bounces to slightly in the green following the FOMC policy statement more concerned with slowing growth, rising interest rates, and slowing inflation than with tapering QE purchases.
    • GLD -0.1%, IAU -0.2%.
    • Silver reverses course as well.
    • SLV +0.6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:39 PM
  • HES

    Hess seeking partners for assets in Kurdistan, Ghana

    • Hess (HES +2.2%) says in its earnings call it is seeking partners to explore two fields in Iraq's Kurdistan and a block offshore Ghana, as it looks to add to the $3.5B in assets already sold this year and helping send shares higher today.
    • Expects higher production in H2 from North Dakota's Bakken shale due to the transition to pad drilling, in which more wells are sunk from a single spot.
    • Says it is continuing efforts to sell its retail division but provides no details; plans to spin off its midstream Bakken assets into an MLP in 2015.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:33 PM
  • NUVA

    Nuvasive slides on subpoena concerns and a challenging market outlook

    • NuVasive (NUVA -13.6%) slides today as news of a federal subpoena casts uncertainty over the maker of spinal medical devices.
    • NUVA beat the Street's Q2 revenue estimates, but the company disclosed late yesterday a "broad" subpoena by Medicare and Medicaid's IG office regarding potentially false claims.
    • SA contributor Stephen Simpson says that although the subpoena puts blood in the water for the shorts, the company faces bigger challenges from a competitive pricing environment, which could stymie ambitious growth plans.
    • Canaccord agrees, saying that NUVA has overcome salesforce churn and heavier competition, but still has to prove itself in a tough environment for health-care companies.
    • Barclays adds that the company remains challenged by "difficult spine-market dynamics," as well as other factors.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:31 PM
  • CYTX

    Cytori rises on Puregraft sale

    • Cytori Therapeutics (CYTX +6.4%) jumps after the company sells the global manufacturing and commercialization rights for Puregraft to Bimini Technologies for $5M upfront and up to $10M in milestone payments tied to sales of the fat grafting product.
    • Bimini has also acquired the commercialization rights to the Celution System for Alopecia.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM
  • CENX

    Century Aluminum sinks 15% after Q2 results

    • Century Aluminum (CENX -15%) sinks in the wake of Q2 results and worries over weak demand and the potential impact of proposed LME warehousing changes.
    • J.P. Morgan cuts its price target on CENX to $8.50 from $9, noting that "while the new power rates would improve Century's current cost structure... we do not expect they will be correlated with primary LME aluminum prices, which merits a discount given the potential for margin volatility absent any hedging."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:55 PM
  • AMED

    Amedisys gains on a solid Q2 EPS report

    • Amedisys (AMED +8.4%) moves up after its Q2 EPS easily topped forecasts this morning, largely due to lower operating expenses.
    • Net income actually declined 38% from the same quarter last year.
    • Net service revenue fell 13.7% over the same period.
    • For FY13, the company expects to report diluted earnings in the range of $0.45 to $0.55.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:50 PM
  • CMI

    Cummins' quarter impresses Goldman

    • Goldman's Jerry Revich reiterates a Conviction List-Buy on shares of Cummins (CMI +2.6%) following the company's Q2 results.
    • Revich highlights "a $1B new product cycle in CMI's highest margin business" next year, which should "drive significant upside to consensus."
    • Other positives include "meaningfully higher Engine profitability despite continued mix headwinds, a high returns Distribution acquisition, and improving Power Generation cost control."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:41 PM
  • BIOS

    BioScrip announces new credit facilities and results of its tender offer

    • BioScrip (BIOS +2.1%) says it's arranged new credit facilities, in part to finance its acquisition of CarePoint Partners and to buy back outstanding notes.
    • The company has entered into a senior secured first-lien revolving credit facility worth $75M, plus a senior secured first-lien term loan B for $250M and a senior secured first-lien delayed draw term loan B for $150M.
    • The company also says it's received and accepted for purchase approximately $126.2M of its outstanding notes under its tender offer.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:37 PM
  • PSX

    Phillips 66 snaps back as investors re-evaluate

    • Phillips 66 (PSX +4.8%) bounces back from an initial negative reaction to Q2 results as investors realize that, other than production interruptions at its chemicals units, PSX continues to operate its businesses very well.
    • In the earnings call, CEO Greg Garland said his biggest Q2 disappointment was a second power outage at the Sweeny refinery, adding that the power company was the cause of both outages.
    • PSX says it has increased runs of light crude imports at its New Jersey refinery as costs of Bakken crude increased in recent weeks.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:34 PM | 1 Comment
  • NTR

    Uralkali could discuss joint Swiss trading firm with Belarus

    • Although some analysts hold out hope that potash producers Uralkali and Belaruskali can settle their differences and reverse the damage from yesterday's breakup, Uralkali's CEO says it's not happening although he could consider joining with Belarus in a Swiss-based trading company.
    • He believes new global potash projects will be delayed, and sees global potash demand rising to 59M-60M tons in 2014 from 54M-55M tons in 2013.
    • Separately, Potash (POT -4.9%) confirms the Toronto Stock Exchange's approval of a previously announced ~43.35M share repurchase program.
    • MOS -2.8%, IPI -7.4%, AGU -2.1%, SQM -4.9%, CF -0.5%, RNF -1%, TNH -1.3%, UAN -0.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:21 PM | 2 Comments
  • CZR

    Concerns over Caesars Entertainment's debt load

    • Shares of Caesars Entertainment (CZR -7.5%) fall with more talk that the company is heading toward a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing.
    • According to one dour-sounding hedge fund manager, Caesars Entertainment needs "a meteor to destroy the earth" or a big name like Apollo Global Management to come in and buy billions of debt to avert bankruptcy.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:04 PM | 1 Comment
  • CW

    Curtis-Wright lands contract to provide flight data recording system to Irkut

    • Curtiss-Wright (CW +0.7%) moves up today after saying it will supply the flight data recording system for use on the MC-21 aircraft program to Irkut Corporation.
    • The contract has an initial value of $21M and an estimated future value in excess of $50M.
    • Shipment is scheduled to begin in February, 2015.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:02 PM
  • IAC

    InterActiveCorp investors take profits after Q2 beat

    • Though InterActiveCorp's (IACI -7%) Q2 results beat expectations, investors are taking profits following a strong rally from the Internet mini-conglomerate's January lows.
    • Slumping margins might be worrying some investors. IAC's Q2 op. margin was 13.3%, down from 14.3% a year ago. A key reason: IAC's Local and Media units, which include video site Vimeo (seeing "strong growth"), local ad platform CityGrid (seeing declining revenue), and the struggling Newsweek Daily Beast JV, saw a combined $8M op. loss vs. a $4.4M op. profit a year ago.
    • The Search & Applications division (53% of revenue, includes Ask.com) performed well: sales +23% Y/Y (+13% exc. the About.com purchase) and op. income +21% to $89.3M.
    • Match division (online dating) sales +9%; op. income +2% to $58.4M.
    • $73.1M was spent on buybacks.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 1:44 PM
  • MRK

    Piper Jaffray downgrades Trius Therapeutics on the back of its Acquisition by Cubist

    • Piper Jaffray weighs in on Trius Therapeutics (TSRX +16.6%), cutting the shares to Neutral from Overwieght on the back of the acquisition announcement from Cubist (CBST).
    • Cubist (CBST) will pay $13.50 in cash plusÂ one non-tradeable $2.00 contingent value right for TSRX.
    • Under the terms of the deal,Â TSRX shareholders will receive $1 if net tedizolid sales in the U.S., Canada andÂ Europe reach $125M in 2016 and up to another $1 paid on a pro rata basisÂ for the next $10M in 2016 net sales up to $135M.
    • Piper forecasts 2016Â tedizolid sales of $188M, so its sees a good chance that the full $2 CVR will beÂ paid out.
    • That being said, after applying an 18% discount rate back through today, Piper arrives at present CVRÂ value of $1.32, leaving the stock near fair value.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:37 PM
  • REMX

    Rare metals ETF in focus after report of spiking prices

    • Do you know what's in your ETF? The Market Vectors Rare Earth/Strategic Metals ETF (REMX +0.6%) shows little reaction to spiking rare earth stocks amid a report on skying prices in China.
    • Of the rare earth stocks moving higher, only Molycorp is in the ETF's top 10 holdings, a 5.87% stake.

  • AZN

    AstraZeneca signs collaboration deal with Fibrogen to develop anemia drug

    • AstraZeneca (AZN +0.9%) inks a collaboration deal to develop an oral anemia drug with privately held U.S. biotechnology company FibroGen that could potentially be worth more than $815M.
    • The collaboration includes the development and commercialization of FG-4592, a drug that mimics the body's response to being at high altitude, which stimulates production of red blood cells and would be used to treat anemia.
    • AZN's is making an initial $350M payment to FibroGen, will could rise to as much as $815M if development milestones are reached, and possibly even exceed that with royalty payments on future sales in the low 20% range.
    • AZN has made $2.8B worth of acquisition and collaboration deals in the last six months alone in a bid to counteract the revenue-sapping effect of generic competition.
    • The deal is limited to the U.S., China and a few other markets, but excludes Europe, Japan and other markets where FibroGen already has an agreement with Astellas Pharma (OTCPK:ALPMY).
